Type 2 diabetes
column2: in which the body can‚Äôt properly regulate blood sugar
column3: has become so common it‚Äôs almost considered inconsequential. More than 1 in 10 Americans have the disease (though many don't know) and another nearly 4 in 10 are at risk for it. In total
column4: half of all adults and a quarter of teenagers have diabetes or pre-diabetes.

column1: Its financial costs are astronomical. The country spends more than $300 billion a year to address diabetes
column2: accounting for $1 out of every $4 spent on health care.¬†

column1: And its personal tolls are even worse: heart attacks
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: kidney disease
column5: double the risk of premature death. It also causes what‚Äôs known as ‚Äúdiabetes distress
column6: ‚Äù the daily burdens and emotional toll of living with and managing a chronic ailment that can lead to regular dips in energy
column7: foggy thinking and depression
column8: and a sense of isolation.

column1: The most frustrating aspect of Type 2 diabetes
column2: experts say
column3: is that it has long been largely preventable and controllable.¬†

column1: ‚ÄúWe have made tremendous gains in understanding diabetes
column2: ‚Äù said Dr. Donald Berwick
column3: a pediatrician and former administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. ‚ÄúThe best diabetes care can make a very big difference. You can‚Äôt say we don‚Äôt know what to do.‚Äù

column1: And yet
column2: diagnosed rates of Type 2 diabetes have soared over the past 25 years
column3: and especially over the past dozen ‚Äì particularly among working-age adults like Ray
column4: Castrucci and Haynes.¬†

column1: Roughly 40% of people who died early in the coronavirus pandemic had Type 2 diabetes
column2: a rate four times higher than people without the disease. Even when elevated blood sugar levels are below the threshold for type 2 diabetes
column3: the risk for heart disease jumps 30% to 50% compared with people with normal blood sugar levels. (Type 1 diabetes
column4: which accounts for 5% to 10% of diabetes
column5: is caused by the immune system and is unrelated to diet or lifestyle.)

column1: America‚Äôs failure to address Type 2 diabetes highlights larger problems with our food and medical systems
column2: Berwick and other experts said.

column1: A soda costs less than a bottle of water
column2: a double cheeseburger and fries less than a carton of blueberries. Patients wait months for medical appointments only to see the back of a white coat for the short time they‚Äôre allotted. Treating disease costs society far more than preventing it but typically provides more profit for insurance companies
column3: hospitals and the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: The USA TODAY Health team spoke with scores of health care providers
column2: researchers
column3: community leaders and patients for this five-part series to understand why Type 2 diabetes continues to worsen in America despite known solutions.

column1: The answer isn't simple. It involves systemic problems facing everyone in society
column2: not just those with diabetes: a food system designed to sell products; a medical system in which cutting off a leg is less expensive than saving it; the high cost of healthy living and the fact that breaking habits takes a lot more than just personal willpower.

column1: There‚Äôs no question personal responsibility plays a role in fighting diabetes.¬†
Haynes

‚ÄúNobody wants to take 55 pills

column1: Castrucci is a third-generation diabetes patient. The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes if a parent has it is 40%. If both parents have it

column5: ‚Äù he pleaded

On the day Haynes stepped on a rusty nail in 2019
column2: he walked all day as the nail pierced the sole of his sneaker and then his foot. By the time he took off his shoe that night
column3: his foot was infected. He landed in the hospital for two months as doctors and nurses tried
column4: mostly unsuccessfully
column5: to get the infection and Haynes‚Äô blood sugar under control.

column1: By the time he was released
column2: he knew enough about Type 2 diabetes to realize his daily blood sugar levels ‚Äì typically in the mid-400s ‚Äì were four times above what he had been told to shoot for.

column1: But nothing he did or ate seemed to make a difference. He had long since traded ribs for salads
column2: beer for water.¬†

column1: His wife
column2: Angela
column3: barely noticed when James started wearing multiple pairs of socks
column4: pouring powder on his feet and buying bigger shoes. His feet tingled a lot
column5: he said
column6: but he was coping with it.¬†

column1: James ended up in the emergency room again
column2: dehydrated and in need of antibiotics. The doctor amputated the baby toe on his right foot
column3: leaving a large open wound.¬†

column1:
We're going to leave this open because we'll probably have to take more,‚Äù Angela remembered the doctor saying. ‚ÄúI didn't like that we're not going to try to save anything, we're just going to start cutting.‚Äù
James was fading.
His arm muscles shriveled and he lost his Popeye physique. Antibiotics left him looking sickly, his voice so weak Angela could barely hear him. ‚ÄúI felt like I was watching my husband slowly dying,‚Äù she said.
Finally, taking her doctor sister‚Äôs advice, Angela emailed Dr. Foluso Fakorede‚Äôs office to ask for an appointment. She thought it would take months to get James in to see the heart disease specialist, but the office called and asked if they could come the next day.¬†
The Hayneses would end up going back to see Fakorede many times ‚àí sometimes twice in one week, driving more than five hours each way from Gulfport north to Cleveland, Mississippi.
‚ÄúWe started looking forward to these visits because there was always hope,‚Äù Angela Haynes said, though she felt guilty they were taking up so much of the important doctor‚Äôs time.¬†
Fakorede, who is on a personal mission to save people with diabetes from amputations, noticed what other doctors had missed. Haynes had blockages in blood vessels on both legs.¬†
Once he got the blood flowing again, Haynes began to feel better. His flesh returned to its normal color. The wound started healing at last. Walking became easier.
Then disaster struck again.¬†
On July 2, 2022, Haynes caught COVID-19. Everything went downhill after that
column2:
he said.
During his 13-day illness, the bacteria in his foot raged out of control. He ended up back in the hospital and unable to withstand the long drive to Fakorede‚Äôs office.
Every week, a surgeon would come to the door of his hospital room and before even stepping all the way in ask Haynes whether he had decided to get his leg amputated.¬†
This is my leg. I was born with this. And you're walking in like you're cutting a piece of cake
column3:
Haynes said.
He was worried about how he‚Äôd get around, how he‚Äôd be able to work to support his family if he had only one leg. No one took the time to explain why they thought the leg needed to come off or how he‚Äôd cope without it, Haynes said.¬†
In late November, he was finally sent home in a wheelchair. But just three weeks later, as he was getting out of the car after wound care, his right leg gave out and he fell to the ground. Back at the hospital, Haynes was told his foot was broken, essentially beyond repair. He agreed to a below-the-knee amputation.
Released right before Christmas, he spent the next three weeks in bed wondering how he‚Äôd manage the rest of his life.
Finally, it looked as if his luck might be turning around.
With the leg gone, his diabetes improved. His blood sugar dropped into the 120s or one-teens. His blurry vision cleared up.
During his long hospital stay, he befriended nurses and learned about a program for people who needed prostheses. The man who ran it called early in the year and said he had received a donated leg. If it fit Haynes, he could have it while waiting for insurance to pay for a personalized one. Miraculously, it did.¬†
Haynes spent the next six months teaching himself to walk again. The donor leg was heavy and uncomfortable. He wasn't mobile enough to hold down a job.
One late spring night, picking up dinner at a nearby restaurant, he headed to the bathroom for a pit stop. A sink had been leaking all day and Haynes slipped in the puddle, falling backward.
He's still recovering from the resulting wrist surgery.
He and Angela are living ‚Äì barely ‚Äì off her part-time salary as a secretary and a church organist.
Haynes has tried at least three or four times" to receive government assistance
column4: but they keep losing his paperwork
column5: or not believing he's disabled
column6: though he once checked himself out of the hospital and arrived at an appointment in his wheelchair to prove he didn't have a leg.

column1: Still
column2: he clings to his faith and the positive attitude he has long used to cheer up himself and others. These are his secret weapons against diabetes and everything else life throws his way.

column1: I try to put a smile on other people's faces, he said. "It keeps my day going."

CPI stands for the consumer price index. It is a metric used by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics to gauge how much the price of consumer goods and services has changed over time.
It can effectively measure inflation in an urban market and give government officials and everyday citizens alike an idea of the health of the overall economy.

column2: released in early August
column3: showed that consumer prices in July rose 3.2% from a year earlier

column1: In the most basic sense
column2: inflation is measured by comparing the current price of goods and services against their recent history.

column1: This is done by looking at¬†a number of government-released data reports.
The CPI is the most prominent of these metrics. Released by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics
column2: the consumer price index measures the prices of goods in an urban market
column3: which represents over 90% of the American public.

column1: The CPI looks at a 'fixed basket' of some 80
column2: 000 goods and services to come up with these numbers. What gets put in that basket depends on the consumer expenditures survey which polls Americans to determine which goods are important. The importance of those goods then determines their weight in the CPI‚Äì for example
column3: the price of something like gasoline
column4: which forms an integral part of many people‚Äôs cost of living
column5: will contribute more than other items.

column1: The CPI does not just have one version though.

Another version ‚Äì the chained consumer price Index for all urban consumers is used to adjust tax brackets. The virtue of the chained CPI is that it takes into account the product substitutions shoppers make
column2: which happens often when prices go up amid inflation. In doing this
column3: it provides a more accurate look at consumer spending and doesn‚Äôt overstate inflation.

column1: Inflation can also be measured through the price index for personal consumption expenditures (PCE). This metric
column2: released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis
column3: takes a more holistic view. Rather than calculating the change in prices for goods paid solely out of pocket for consumers

Vopson's latest research stems from the abstract concept that¬†information is the fundamental building block of the universe¬†and has both energy and physical mass.
My questions was, where is that information going when the bit is at equilibrium and is stored information? he said in the Youtube video. "Energy can't exist on its own

column1: It's the belief of Vopson and others working in the field of science known as information physics that our physical reality could be made up of bits of information
column2: which aren't unlike the cells of living organisms that are coded with DNA containing valuable information about themselves.

column1: After studying¬†digital data storage and an RNA genome
column2: Vopson discovered in 2022 that information systems don't appear to conform to the second law of thermodynamics. That law essentially dictates that any naturally occurring process will result in a loss of energy and increase in a system's measure of disorder
column3: or entropy (think of an ice cube that gradually melts when placed in a cup of water at room temperature.)

column1: In fact
column2: Vopson discovered that the entropy in information systems actually decreases
column3: leading him to establish what he calls the second law of information dynamics.

column4: symmetry and yes
